In 2009, Natividad joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Natividad has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Natividad is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Natividad from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Men

texts.en:
Men S., 42, is married and resides with her husband and seven children in, Cambodia, in an area known for pre-Angkorean temples.

S. sells green coconuts for an income of about USD $10 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD $10 per day. Her husband and S. also have a business of using the balloons for people to break.

S. is requesting a loan of USD $1200 to purchase a new motorbike and eggs to grill for sale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support the children’s study. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike and eggs to grill for sale

loans.name: Teleuli

texts.en:
Teleuli F. is 38 years old and married. She hash 7 children, ages 2 - 21,  She is starting a taxi business. Teleuli needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase fuel. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Teleuli joined SPBD. This is her first loan from SPBD. SPBD's loans are Teleuli's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375"

loans.name: Mrs. Sreu Pov Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty-two people make up a village bank loan located in Ba Srae village in Takeo province. Mrs. Sreu P. is the village bank president, selected by the other members who will each use their share of the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Sreu P. owns a general store in the local village to earn some money to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Nouv S., is a farmer who owns a half-hectare of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. The field is ready for farming but they do not have enough money to support it. To improve production, Mrs. Sreu P. is seeking a loan to buy rice seed and to start a new business breeding pigs. The couple supports three children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the other attends the local public school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and piglets

loans.name: Afutiti

texts.en:
Afutiti Saulaulu is 28 years old and married. She has 4 children, ages 1 - 10.  She is starting a business planting, harvesting, and selling taro. Afutiti needs a loan of WST$1000 to purchase weed-killers, such as Gramoxome. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Afutiti joined SPBD. This is her 1st loan from SPBD. SPBD's loans are Afutiti's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan S., 45, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Cambodia, in an area known for pre-Angkorean temples.

S. is a farmer and grows rice for an income of about USD $1 per day. Her husband raises ducks for eggs to sell, earning an income of USD $14 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD $1000 to purchase more ducks to raise for eggs. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair the house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more ducks to raise for eggs

loans.name: Faye Jade

texts.en:
Faye Jade P. is from the village of Magsaysay , Gingoog City. She is 24 years old. Faye Jade is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Faye Jade owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling electronic loads for all cellphone networks in the local community. Faye Jade has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Faye Jade joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Faye Jade has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Faye Jade is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Faye Jade from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Mrs. Seang Chey Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This is a village bank loan in Ba Srae village in Takeo province consisting of eight people. All the members will use their share of the loan for different purposes to improve the living conditions of their families.

The members selected Mrs. Seang C. as the village bank president. She is 54 years-old. She is a farmer who owns a two-hectare of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Soeurng Morm, is a palm juice collector who earns some money from selling palm sugar to support his family. Although they work hard they earn insufficient income. So to improve the family living conditions, Mrs. Seang C. is applying for a loan to buy some piglets for breeding to start a new business. They will also use the rest of the loan to buy fertilizer to do farming. From this activity, they support four children, one of whom is a teacher in the local village and the others are studying in local public school.

loans.use: To buy some piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Mrs. Chanthal Taen Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This is a village bank loan consisting of seventeen people in Trapeang Krouch village in Takeo province.  The members have selected Mrs. Chanthal T. as the village bank president. 

Mrs. Chanthal T. was born in 1963. She is a farmer who owns two-hectares of land to cultivate rice to sell to support the family.  She also breeds pigs. Her challenge is that her field has infertile soil. In order to improve production, Mrs. Chanthal T. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer. She will use the rest of the loan to buy rice seeds and pesticides.  Her husband, Mr. Van Brak, is a teacher at the local school. This couple does not have children, so they live in a three person household. 

Mrs. Ra Ten and Mrs. Run Ham are group guarantors so they are also present in the photo. All the members are shown in the picture save for one of them who is blocked.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Mrs. Thy Kaim Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Thy K. is 24 years-old. She is the village bank president as selected by nine members. The group loan is located in Trapeang Krouch village in Takeo province. This village bank loan has been made up by all the members who will use their share of the loan to do something that can improve their businesses. 

Mrs. Thy K. is a door-to-door mosquito net, scarf and blanket seller. Her husband, Mr. Chrey Val, is a famer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family.  Their problem is that her husband’s field has infertile soil. In order to improve production, Mrs. Thy K. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer. She will use the rest of the loan to hire a plow machine to plow her field. This couple does not have a child.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Nicolas

texts.en:
Nicolas N. is from the town of Banga. He is 52 years old and married, and he has 2 school-aged children. He is involved in farming. He plants and harvests corn crops for sale. He also started raising hogs recently. He hopes for his ventures to be successful someday. Nicolas has been engaged in his business for over 45 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nicolas joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nicolas has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Nicolas is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and feed for his hogs. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Nicolas from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds, and other farm inputs

To make a living, Flordeliza owns and operates a business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Flordeliza has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 50,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) during harvest season.

In 2006, Flordeliza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flordeliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Flordeliza is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Flordeliza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

Mrs. Voeun Voeun was selected by the other members of her group as their village bank president. She is 25 years old. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice that she sells to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Kha Khoem, is a broom seller door-to-door. Both of them work hard at their businesses but they still do not earn much. For that reason, they wanted to start a new business but they did not have enough money to invest in it. Thus, Mrs. Voeun Voeun is seeking a loan to buy some piglets for breeding. Through this activity, they hope to support their five children, all of wH. attend local public school.

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
64-year-old Perla N. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Perla owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Perla has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Perla joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Perla has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Perla is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. She also plans to acquire three piglets to raise. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Perla from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Ligaya

texts.en: Ligaya T. is from the town of Capatan, Tuguegarao City. She is 56 years old. Ligaya is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Ligaya runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products, such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Ligaya has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Ligaya joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ligaya has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI, a Kiva partner. Ligaya is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Ligaya from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean P. is from the village of Talisayan, Misamis Oriental. She is 39 years old. Jean is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Jean owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Jean has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jean joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jean has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Jean is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jean from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and support her children's education..

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Vaipanoa

texts.en:
Vaipanoa V. is 46 and married with six children (ages 3 - 18).  She owns a business venture, 0.  Vaipanoa has one year of experience in this business. Vaipanoa needs a loan of WST $1,000 0.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Vaipanoa joined SPBD.  This is her first loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Vaipanoa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD: 

In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as to Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD:  http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.name: Donna

texts.en:
Donna D. is from the village of Little Tadian. She is 25 years old. Donna is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Donna owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Donna is just starting this business.

In 2010, Donna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Donna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Donna is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Donna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Mr. Ra Nhil Village Bank Group

texts.en:
In Aopheasang village in Takeo province live these eleven people who make up this village bank loan. Mr. Ra N., 28 years old, is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members. Each member will use the loan for a different purpose.

Mr. Ra N.’s occupation is a motorbike taxi driver. His wife, Mrs. S. Much Tey, is a frog and palm seller in her local market. Since his wife’s business is going well he wants to expand it. So, to improve this business, Mr. Ra N. is applying for a loan to buy more frogs and palms for his wife to resell.

Mr. Ra N. is the father of two children, one of whom is enrolled in the local public school, while the other is a year old.

loans.use: To buy more frogs and palms for his wife's business

Ligarda owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP whenever she sells her raised animal. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Ligarda is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. loans.name: Rodney

texts.en:
Rodney B. is from the town of Banga. He is 25 years old. Rodney is single. To make a living, Rodney owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Rodney has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Rodney joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodney has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Rodney is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed and baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Rodney from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

Mrs. Thea C. was born in 1973 and her occupation is a frog and palm seller at her local market. Since her business is goI. well she wants to expand it. So, to improve her business, she is askI. for a loan to buy more frogs and palm to resell.

Mrs. Thea C. is widow who lives with six members in her household.

Erlinda owns and operates a business planting and harvesting decorative plants for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. loans.name: Rysbubu's Group

texts.en:
Rysbubu Z. is the leader of the group. She is 49 and a widow. She has raised a son and a daughter. The daughter is married and lives separately with her family and the son has a job, but when he has free time he helps his mom. Rysbubu has been breeding cattle, fattening sheep and selling milk for 25 years. 

In the beginning, she saved money from her salary and bought a calf. The initial investment in this business was 1000 soms ($21.76)and now in this way she makes 1800 soms ($36.16)per month. That profit made it possible for her to purchase a vehicle and contribute some money to her daughter's wedding. Now Rysbubu wants to get a loan to purchase a bull in order to resell it after fattening and make some money.

Asel M. is 23. Her husband works at a brick factory. They have three sons; the eldest one is five years old. In order to make some money Asel breeds cattle and sells milk. In this way she makes 4500 soms ($97.90) per month. With money received from the loan she will buy a bull-calf for breeding.

Kalyibubu B. is the treasurer of the group. She is 53 and divorced. She has raised three daughters and a son. The older daughter is married and lives separately with her family. The younger daughter studies at university. The other went to work to Russia in order to earn some money. Kalyibubu has been breeding sheep and selling milk for 25 years. She makes 6000 soms ($130.55) per month. Kalyibubu applied for the loan, because she needs money to build a shed.

Tamarahan K. is 50, and she is a widow. She has a son and two daughters. The son is 25, and he is married and works in a prison. The older daughter is married too and she lives separately with her family. The younger daughter studies at university.  Two years ago, with the initial investment of 15000 soms ($326.37) Tamarahan bought a kiosk and began to sell convenience goods. In this way she makes 5000 soms ($108.8) per month. Tamarah want to get a loan because she needs money to pay for treatment.  In the future she wants to open a big store.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase a bull in order to resell it after fattening

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanny N. is 56 years old and she lives in Samna Khmau village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns two hectares (5 acres) of land to cultivate rice for a living. Aside from farming she is also a pig breeder and is able to earn a small income to support her family.

In order to increase her income to improve her family’s living standard, Mrs. Vanny N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding.

Mrs. Vanny N. is a widow with five children: two are seamstresses in the garment factory, one is a car taxi driver, while the other two are students.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

Mrs. Yeng N. is a farmer who owns two hectares (5 acres) of land on which she cultivates rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Korn Keov, is a rice middleman and he alS. charges batteries for a fee.

Since her husband’s business is going well Mrs. Yeng N. wants to expand it. S., to improve his business, she is requesting loan to buy more rice to resell.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Mrs. Touch B., a 57-year-old farmer, lives in Smaong village in Takeo Province where she owns 1.50 hectares of land upon which she cultivates rice and also breeds pigs. Both businesses provide a small income that helps to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Saroeun Preap, is a police officer.

Touch is now requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, pay for the rental of a water machine and farm labor, and to buy piglets and pig food for pig breeding. This couple has two children; one is a driver, while the other works at a casino.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, to pay for rental of a water machine and farm labor, and to buy piglets and pig food

Her husband, Mr. Poeun Maen (pictured with her), earns a small income through his work as a motorbike taxi driver. The couple has four children – one is a seamstress in a garment factory while the other three are students and also support their mother's businesses.
In order to increase the family income, Mrs. Ya E. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding.

Aside from farming, she is also a congee (rice porridge) seller, from which she earns a small income to support her family.
To support her farm, Mrs. Phon T. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide and to pay a laborer to plow her farm.

texts.en:
Mrs. Nharn T. is a 27-year-old married woman who lives Tuol Svay village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Savoeun Nhorng, are farmers who own one and a half hectare of land on which they cultivate rice. 

Aside from being a farmer on her own land, Mrs. Nharn T. is also farm laborer where she can receive a small salary to support her family's needs. 

To support her crop, Mrs. Nharn T. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline. 

This couple has two children who both are attending the local school.

Avatea needs a loan of WST$ 2000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US$ 250 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Avatea joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Avatea's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 

In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375"

Norman E. is from the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. He is 47 years old. Norman is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Norman owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling food & daily use products as well as spices and some veggies in the local community. Norman has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Norman joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norman has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Norman is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Norman from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

loans.name: Melly

texts.en:
Melly A. is a 52-year-old widow who supports her family by running a general store business. She lives in Phase III, Blk 7, Lot 7, Urban San Carlos City, Negros Occidental with her three children aged between 18 and 32 years. Two of her children work and the other is currently in school.
Melly has been a member of Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, since 2005. She has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 5,000 PHP.
Melly is now borrowing 10,000 PHP as additional working capital for her general store. This will be her 17th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 10,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Melly aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the 'Dungganon' way.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.name: Vicitation

texts.en:
Vicitation B. is a 64-year-old married woman who lives in the village of Gil Montilla in Sipalay City in the province of Negros Occidental. She earns her living through her general store and through farming. Vicitation's husband, David, is a farmer. They have seven children. Six of their children already have their own families, and only one child is single and works to help the family.

Vicitation joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999, in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve their family's quality of life. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a general store business and by farming. Now she earns an average monthly income of 15,500 PHP from her business activities.

Vicitation is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of 19,000 PHP was used to fund the operations of her general store, and it had a positive impact in both the business and her family's living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 16th loan, a loan in the amount of 15,000 PHP, which she intends to use for her general store and for farming. Vicitation is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide her family with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than 1 USD a day by achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

texts.en:
Rodolfo B. is from the town of Banga. He is 48 years-old. and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Rodolfo owns and operates a business in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Rodolfo has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Rodolfo joined Kiva partner CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodolfo has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Rodolfo is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farm inputs. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Rodolfo from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly in recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.en: Elisabeth R. is a 66-year-old married woman who lives in Barangay Bagawines, Vallehermoso, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store and an eatery. Elisabeth’s husband, Ernesto, is a 71-year-old retired employee and they have seven children who are between 30 and 47 years old. Six of her children have their own families while one is still single and works to help support the family. Elisabeth joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a general store and an eatery business. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 3,000 from her business activities. Elisabeth is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 8,000 was used to fund operations of her general store and eatery business and it had a positive impact on both the business and on the family’s living conditions. Now, she is borrowing Php 10,500 as her 17th loan which she intends to use as additional capital for her general store and eatery business. Elisabeth is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Erkin's Group

texts.en:
Erkin T., 48, is the leader of the group. Her husband works as a mechanic and his monthly wage is 5000 soms ($108.81). They have two daughters and two sons. The first son works in Bishkek at the furniture factory, and the second one works at a school for electricians. The older daughter is 22, married, and lives separately with her family. The younger daughter studies at school. Twenty years ago, Erkin started to breed and sell cattle; the initial investment in this business activity was 1000 soms ($21.76). Now she earns 5000 soms ($108.81) per month. That profit made it possible for her to purchase home furniture, a vehicle and contribute some money to her son and her daughter's weddings. With money received from this loan Erkin wants to purchase five animals at 4000 soms ($87) per animal. In the future, she wants to expand her business so that she can build an adequate washroom for her family.

Rahima S. is the treasurer of the group, she is 41. Her husband is a farmer. They have three daughters and a son. The older daughter studies in Germany and also works there. The other children study at school. Rahima and her husband have been breeding and fattening cattle for 15 years. They also cultivate fruits and vegetables. Then they sell them at a higher price. In this way Rahima makes 8000 soms ($174) per month. Now she wants to get a loan to pay a tractor driver for his services and purchase 100 liters of fuel, which is needed for the summer season sowing process.

Balbubu B. is 52 and is married. She has raised four sons and two twin daughters. All of them are working, except for the youngest son, who goes to school. Seven years ago Balbubu got a loan of 4000 soms ($87) and started her business activity. Balbubu and her husband breed cattle and cultivate fruits and vegetables. Today, she wants to get a loan to purchase 100 litters of fuel, which is needed for sowing process and to pay the tractor driver for his services.

Zeinur T. is 48 and she is married. She has three daughters and a son. Two daughters work in a factory, the others study at school. Zaeinur and her husband have been breeding and selling cattle for five years. They started this business with the initial investment of 5000 soms ($108.81) and now they earn 5000 soms ($108.81) a month. Zeunir applied for a loan because she needs money to purchase sugar to produce jam.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeun T. is 52 years old and lives in Tuol Svay village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Arn Se, are farmers who own 1.50 hectares of land to cultivate rice for a living. Aside from being a farmer, Mr. Arn Se also works as a farm laborer to earn a little salary to support his family. 

For her farm, Mrs. Saroeun T. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer and to pay for a laborer to plow her farm. 

This couple has six children; five are students who also support their parents' farming, while the youngest child is 6 years old.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and to pay for a laborer to plow her farm

loans.name: Sabira's Group

texts.en:
Sabira K. is the leader of this group; she is 68. Her husband is a pensioner. They have five daughters and three sons. All the children are married and lives separately with their families, except the youngest son. Sabira and her husband have been breeding cattle for twenty years. Their youngest son helps them in this activity. In this way they make money to improve their living conditions. With money received from this loan, Sabira will purchase one cow for breeding. In the future she wants to increase the number of cattle.

Aigul A. is 47; she is a widow. She has raised four daughters and two sons. The sons work in Bishkek as mechanics; the older daughter is a nurse and the second daughter works in a sewing workshop. The other children study at school. Aigul breeds cattle; she has been doing for four years. Now she has applied for a loan because she needs money to purchase one cow in order to increase their number.

Aishabubu A. is 61; she is a widow. She has a son and two daughters. The daughters are married and live separately with their families. The son lives with his mom, and he helps her with housework. Aishabubu has been breeding cattle and cultivating fruits and vegetables for 16 years. She wants to get a loan to purchase 150 litters of fuel, which is needed for the sowing process in the summer season.

Anarbubu AA. is the treasurer of the group. She is 54 and married. She has a son and a daughter. The daughter is married and lives separately with her family. Anarbubu and her husband have been breeding and selling cattle for six years. They started with an initial investment of 10000 soms ($217.6) and now they make 5000 soms ($108.8) per month. Anarbubu needs a loan to purchase cattle and sell it at higher price after fattening.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team, Supporters of Kyrgyzstan, at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak

loans.use: To purchase cattle for breeding

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
A 43-year-old widowed mother of seven children, for the past ten years Mary A. O. has operated her pharmacy, known as Nyombei Pharmacy, out of her home in Manyatta in Kisumu. Selling drugs such as painkillers and antibiotics to the local households, Mary says a major challenge for the business is not being able to reach out to as many people as she would like to. Nonetheless, the business is profitable, enabling her to provide employment to four people.

Mary will use her loan of Kes 20,000 to purchase more drugs to grow her business, hoping to eventually open a shop for her enterprise; from the additional income she hopes to acquire a piece of land. She describes herself as hardworking and always willing to help the needy

loans.use: To purchase additional drugs

loans.name: Saroem

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroem M. is 59 years old and lives in Trapeang Prei village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. She is also grocery seller who owns a small store to support her business. 

Since her grocery business is going well, Mrs. Saroem M. wants to expand it. Therefore, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase more groceries to enlarge her business activities. 

Her husband, Mr. Nat Eam, practices traditional medicine to add a little income to his wife's to support the family. This couple has four children: two are car mechanics; one is staying at home; and the last one is attending the local school.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene H. is from the village of Little Tadian. She is 25 years old. Arlene is married and has 1 infant-aged child. To make a living, Arlene owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Arlene is just starting this business.

In 2010, Arlene joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Arlene is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Arlene from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Linet

texts.en: Linet is a 39-year-old married woman who runs a shop called "Mama Elena" on Jogoo Road in the Mukuru Kwa Njenga slums. In her shop, she sells sugar, soap, rice, maize flour, cereals, and cosmetics. She was formerly operating a salon. She has been earning income from her shop for the past eight years. Linet, who is the mother of four school-going children, strives to provide for the basic needs for her family and to educate her children. She also uses part of her profits, both from her shop and her van, which she uses for commercial transport, to pay her employee and save some money in a borrowing group under Faulu Kenya. She dreams of expanding her shop into a supermarket in the future. For this reason, she plans to add stock so that she can expand the business. She has requested a loan of KES 70,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy sugar, soap, rice, maize flour, cereals, and cosmetics.

loans.use: To buy sugar, soap, rice, maize flour, cereals, and cosmetics.

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en:
Reynaldo O. is from the village of Barangay 17, Gingoog City. He is 48 years old. Reynaldo is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Reynaldo owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store and also sells fish. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food, daily use products and a variety of fish in the local market. Reynaldo has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Reynaldo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Reynaldo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. Reynaldo is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be Reynaldo's third loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine is married to a businessman and she also runs a retail shop. She sells sugar, sweets, soaps, maize flour, and cooking fat and has been in this business for seven years. She also farms to earn more income. She uses her income to pay wages to her two employees and help her husband pay the household expenses. She joined a group called "Tueane" in Faulu Kenya and she saves her money with the group on a weekly basis. In this group, she can easily get a loan from Faulu Kenya because the group members guarantee each other's loans. She has requested a loan of KES 60,000 to add to her stock of cosmetics. Christine is 28 years old and a mother of two.

loans.use: To buy sugar, sweets, soaps, maize flour, and cooking fat.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda M. is from the village of Gosi Sur, Tuguegarao City. She is 39 years old. Erlinda is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Erlinda owns and operates a specialized store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes  from selling a variety of fruits and vegetables in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

Erlinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Erlinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhorn K. is a 30-year-old married woman who lives in Thmei village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. To support her farming, Mrs. Sokhorn K. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide, and to pay a laborer to plow her farm. 

Mrs. Sokhorn K. also sells groceries and snacks at home in order to earn a small income to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Chantha Oem, is a laborer and fisherman who earns a small income to add to his wife's saving to improve their family's standard of living. This couple has two children: one is a student in the local school and the younger one is a year old. Mrs. Sokhorn K.'s husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide and to pay a laborer to plow her farm

loans.name: Alfonce

texts.en: Alfonce is a 48-year-old married man with three children in school. He has been running a retail shop to earn a living. He also farms to earn extra income. Since he joined Faulu Kenya as part of a group called "Kitooni", he has managed to invest in his business through his savings. Alfonce is the breadwinner in his family and he works hard to provide for the family. He has requested a loan of KES 40,000 to add to his stock of maize flour, cooking fat, sugar, and salt. He hopes to own a piece of land in the future.

loans.use: To buy maize flour, cooking fat, sugar, and salt.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina B. is from the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 46 years old. Angelina is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Angelina owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Angelina has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Angelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelina is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be Angelina's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business.

loans.name: Federico

texts.en:
Federico R. is from the village of Brgy.Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 52 years old and widowed. To make a living, Federico owns and operates a business venture in the services sector providing transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating jeepney transport services. Federico has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Federico joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Federico has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase a new engine. Federico is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP, which will be used to repair his existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Federico from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair his vehicle for better service

loans.name: Bwijenje Twetungure, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
With his small savings from his previous retail shop business, M. Denis, the married father of two at his age of 30, was able to start up his coffee trade business. He goes to farmers directly and makes purchases of raw coffee berries which he dries and takes to factories for resale. This earns him a clear profit of 150,000 Ugandan shillings on a weekly basis.

Therefore, with this loan, Denis looks forward to collecting more stock for his store and expanding his business in the short run. Earning more revenue is his main motive because he will become financially stable and able to take care of his family and also live a self-sustaining life.

loans.use: To restock his business with coffee berries from suppliers

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is 62 years old, married, and has five children. She has been selling vegetables since 2006 and also sells charcoal to supplement her income.

Since she joined Faulu Kenya under the group called Githunguri Wisdom, Cecilia has been able to service two loans which she used to boost her business. This has also enabled her to improve her living standards.

Her group members trust her; they have guaranteed her another loan of Kes 25,000. She plans to use this loan to buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To add to her stock of vegetables

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George N. is from the village of Linao East, Tuguegarao City. He is 33 years old. George is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, George ownsand& operates a business venture in the services sector operating a transportation business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle transport  to local community members. George has been engaged in his business for over 12 years and earns approximately 7200 PHP a month for these activities.

George joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. George has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. George is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase equipment to improve the business. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by George from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to his house. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Kun

texts.en:
Kun S., 29, sells CDs, VCDs and refill gas from home, making US$5 each day in Kandal province. She is married and has two young children living at home to support. Her husband, Bou S., is on the private staff of a local company. He makes approximately US$8 every day.

Kun would like a loan of US$1,000 to set up a grocery store so that her income will increase daily.

loans.use: To set up a grocery store

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena A. is from the village of Linao East, Tuguegarao City. She is 53 years old. Magdalena is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Magdalena owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Magdalena has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP whenever she sells a pig she has raised.

In 2005, Magdalena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Magdalena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. Magdalena is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and then sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and then sell

loans.name: Noah

texts.en:
Noah, 28, is married and has one child. He has been farming for four years. He is the breadwinner in his family and works hard to support the family.

Noah is an active member of the Kyeni Ngeleu group in Faulu Kenya and attends their weekly meetings regularly. He also pays his weekly dues well. He plans to service his second loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya. With this loan, he plans to buy manure and animal feeds.

loans.use: To buy manure and animal feeds

Aigul and her husband have been breeding and selling cattle for twenty years. In this way they make money to improve their living conditions. With money received from the loan Aigul will purchase more cattle in order to increase their number. Nazgul A. is 37 and her husband is a welder. They have a seven-year-old daughter and a four-year-old son. Nazgul and her husband breed and sell cattle. In their village it is the main source of making money. Nazgul wants to get a loan to purchase another cow for breeding. Mairamkan U. is 59 and married. She has four daughters and a son: two daughters are married and live separately with their families; the younger daughter goes to school; and the son helps Mairamkan to take care of her cattle. She wants to get a loan for family needs. Bakytkan A. is 32 and married. She has three sons and a daughter: the daughter and two sons study at school; the third son is just a three-year-old. A year ago, Bakytkan opened a kiosk where she sells convenience goods. The initial investment in that business activity was 10,000 soms (approximately 217 USD) and now she makes 8,000 soms (approximately 173 USD) per month. loans.name: Joshua

texts.en: Joshua O. O., 32, is married but has no children yet.  His thriving tailoring business, called the Nyaimbo Shop, makes clothes for women and  is located near a residential area known as Manyatta in Kisumu,  In business for two years now, Joshua says his only major challenge is the distance he has to walk to get the materials needed for making the clothing. He will be using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy an additional sewing machine and a table so as to grow his business. Hardworking and polite, Joshua hopes to expand his business and provide employment to the local people. He also hopes to acquire rental houses to add to his income.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and table.

loans.name: Kazinga Development Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
In the village of Kazinga, deep in Kihihi, exists a hardworking B. Benon who has run a rice business in Kihihi town for close to three years. The happily married father of six children has maneuvered through tough times before getting to where he is now; as a matter of fact, determination has brought him this far.

This loan will help Benon to do more research on better qualities of rice and to restock his business in order to match his customers’ demand. With an improved business he will be able to earn more revenue and be able to cover his family's needs including his children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for his business

loans.name: Gaudiosa

To make a living, she runs a sari-sari (or variety) store where she sells food and other items people need daily. She has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2009, Gaudiosa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid two previous loans from HSPFI and is now applying for a new one for 10,000 PHP to buy additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by her business to continue expanding it.

loans.name: Hasfa

texts.en:
Hasfa is a single mother of four children and all her children go to school. She resides in and rents a three roomed house.  The family has access to electricity but do not have piped water. Hasfa also takes care of additional family members.

She owns a stall selling sugar canes in Kalerwe market and sells to all categories of people but on wholesale only. She buys these sugar canes in  Kawolo in Mukono district and uses public transport to and from Kawolo for the sugar canes. Hasfa goes for sugar canes once a week.

She wants to use this loan to buy one lorry load of sugar canes. Hasfa has been in this business for 10 years. Hasfa receives an average of 20 customers a day. Her business challenges includes transportation and defaulters.  She aspires to increase on her capital base and start going to Kawolo twice a week. She joined MCDT to get more capital for her sugar cane business.  Her monthly expenses includes rent, food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy one lorry of sugar canes

loans.name: Eldard

texts.en:
Diehard agriculturalist T. Eldard has been maintaining a banana plantation and a pineapple garden for more than fifteen years in Kahija, Bushenyi, and this fetches him 80,000 Ugandan Shillings per week. Though this is not enough to sustain his family of eight children, he has persevered to keep it growing.

Eldard's aim in taking up this loan is to enable him to buy mulches for his plantations and also to hire additional laborers as he looks at his expansion plan and thinks of transporting his produce to bigger markets. This will help him earn more revenue and enable him to live a more sustaining life.

loans.use: To purchase mulches and hire more laborers

In 2009, Samuel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Samuel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to repair his existing vehicle in order to provide better service. This loan will be his second from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn M. is from the village of Malalinta. She is 42 years-old and married with two school-aged children.  Evelyn owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2008, Evelyn joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand the product offering. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Evelyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en: Julius K. N. is 60 years old and married. His wife is a farmer and they have six children. He runs a livestock business in Mwingi and goes to market every workday to sell cows, goats and hides. He has been in this business for two years and says his major challenge is transport of livestock to market. In addition to livestock, he also raises cereal crops such as millet, sorghum and maize. Julius has applied for a loan of Kes 15,000 to expand his business by buying more livestock to sell. In the future, he hopes to buy a vehicle to make it easier to transport his animals to market. He is hardworking, patient, humble and very friendly.

loans.use: to buy more cows, goats and hides to sell to his customers

texts.en:
Carlos M. is from the village of Linao East, Tuguegarao City. He is 55 years-old and married with six adult children. Carlos owns and operates a  furniture making business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling bedroom furniture to local businesses and community members. Carlos has been engaged in his business for over 7 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Carlos joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carlos has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. Carlos is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand his product offering. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Carlos from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children.

loans.name: Nyanama Tweyogerere Society, Kampala Group

texts.en:
N. Robinah is the mother of ten children, all in high school. She also takes care of three orphans. 

For the last ten years, Robinah has been operating a restaurant business in Nyanama, Kampala. With the profits from this business, this hardworking woman has managed to greatly improve her family's welfare in subsequent years. By her own account, in a month she makes profits totaling up to 100,000 shillings.

Robinah's future plans are to expand her business so that it is able to fully compete in an increasingly competitive business field. With this loan, she foresees this unfolding. She wants to buy more furniture like chairs, tables and also cutlery for her growing restaurant business.

loans.use: To purchase new furniture and utensils for her restaurant

loans.name: Rusalinda

texts.en:
Rusalinda G. lives in the village of Quiboro in Camiguin Province. She is 27 years old, widowed and has two school-aged children. To earn a living, she has just gone into business making and selling food, primarily snacks and local delicacies.

Earlier this year, Rusalinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She is requesting a  loan of 5,000 PHP to buy ingredients needed to make more items to sell to her customers. She will use the additional income generated by this loan to improve her family's living conditions.  

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Mabinty

texts.en: Mabinty is a hardworking and very determined businesswoman.  She lives at Isha Street Makeni and and has her business centre at Church Street Makeni.  She is married to a trader who is also an active partner in the business and they have seven dependents.  She was initially financed by her husband and began trading junk (used clothing) which she has now done for 14 years.  She is in need of a loan to increase her stock and also intends to use the proceeds of her loan to help their children acquire university education and construct a dwelling house for herself and their family.

loans.use: To buy used clothing.

loans.name: Ainakan's Group

texts.en: Ainakan D. is the leader of the group. She is 60 and a widow. She has three daughters, all of whom are married. Two of her daughters live separately with their families, while the second daughter lives with her mom. Ainakan has been breeding cattle and cultivating fruits and vegetables for 16 years. (After the USSR collapsed, the collective farms broke up in 1994 and people were able to keep some parts of land and continue to farm it.) Her second daughter and her son-in-law help her in this activity. With money received from the loan, Ainakan will purchase 100 liters of fuel, which is needed for the sowing process in the summer season. Usonbek S. is 40 and married. He has two daughters and three sons. The older daughter and two sons study at school. The other children are too young, so Usonbek's wife stays at home and takes care of them. In order to make money, Usonbek works as a private driver. He wants to get a loan to purchase 180 liters of fuel, which is needed to sow potatoes. Sarylbubu S. is 55 and married. She has three sons and a daughter. The younger son is 19 and he studies at school, while the others are married and live separately with their families. Sarylbubu and her husband have been breeding cattle and cultivating fruits and vegetables for 15 years. With money received from the loan, Sarylbubu will also purchase fuel, which is needed for the sowing process. Zhyldyz I. is 45. She is the treasurer of the group. She has three daughters and two sons. The older daughter is married and lives separately with her family. The older son is 19 and he went to work to Bishkek to earn some money. The other children study at school. Zhyldyz and her husband have been breeding cattle and cultivating fruits and vegetables for 15 years. Now Zhyldyz wants to get a loan to purchase 100 liters of fuel, which is needed for farming. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak

loans.use: To purcase 100 liters of fuel needed for farming

loans.name: Sopey Dabakh Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SOPEY DABAKH  composé est de sept femmes âgées en moyenne de 30 ans et sont toutes mariées exceptée la présidente du groupe Fatou Ndao SALL, et issues du même Banc Villageois qui porte le même nom que celui du quartier DIAMAGUENE. Elles se sont par affinité et solidairement pour s’entre aider à mener leurs activités commerciales constituées généralement de vente de divers produits halieutiques tels des poissons séchés et/ou fumés des huitres et crevettes séchés, la vente de tissus et de produits cosmétiques.
   
Le groupe est l’un des huit qui forment l’assemblée générale dudit Banc Villageois implanté au cœur du quartier et qui compte à son actif 90 membres toutes des femmes. Le groupe a été créé en même temps que le Banc Villageois depuis 2 ans et demi. Madame Astou GUEYE, pour des raisons de maladie de ma maman n’est pas dans la photo, elle devrait l’accompagner pour des soins médicaux à l’hôpital. 

Quant à la présidente Fatou Ndao F., au milieu de la photo exhibant un large sourire et vêtue de boubou blanc parsemé de fleurettes bleues et de pagne bleu, est âgée de 23 ans. Elle est célibataire sans enfant. Grâce à son assiduité et son dynamisme elle a été élue responsable du groupe. Elle vend essentiellement des tissus et des produits cosmétiques. Et l’objet de son crédit est de renforcer son capital d’investissement et son objectif est de renforcer son niveau d’épargne et prendre en charge ses besoins personnels. 

En sus des activités de remboursements ponctuels du groupe, les femmes en manière générale participent à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de leurs familles respectives.
texts.en:
The SOPEY DABAKH solidarity group consists of seven women 30 years old on average, all married excepting the group’s president Fatou Ndao SALL, and all from the same “Banc Villageois” loan group carrying the same name as the DIAMAGUENE borough. They came together through personal affinity and the desire to help each other manage their business activities, mainly concerned with various seafood products such as dried or smoked fish, dried oysters and shrimp, or the sale of clothing fabric and beauty products. The group is one of eight that constitute the “Banc Villageois” loan group, rooted in the centre of the borough and numbering 90 members, all women. The group was created at the same time as the Banc Villageois, 2 ½ years ago. Mrs Aston GUEYE is not in the picture, as she had to take her ailing mother to the hospital for medical treatments. The president Fatou Ndao SALL (23 years old) is in the middle of the picture wearing a wide smile and a white “boubou” strewn with blue flowers and a blue pagne. She is unmarried without children. She was elected group responsible due to her assiduity and dynamism. She retails mainly clothing fabrics and beauty products. The purpose of her loan is to strengthen her working capital and her objective is to bolster her savings and take charge of her personal needs. In addition to reimbursing the group loan, the women contribute in general to the improvement of their respective families’ living conditions.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: reinforce the group's investment capabilities

loans.name: Thac Qua 1-6 Group

texts.en:

In this loan cycle, Duyen would like to borrow 7,194,000 VND in order to buy cloth to make clothes.
