loans.name: Gogaya Women's B, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
In business, first impressions mean everything. That is one adage that never slips N. Teo’s mind. In her six years running a bar business in Mubende town, her commitment, friendly nature and hard work have brought her dividends. This is the fascinating story of a young, single, go-getter business lady.

Teo’s business, since its inception, has been steadily bringing her profits to the tune of 400,000 shillings on a monthly basis. With this loan she is gleefully upbeat that her business will gain further ground as she intends to buy more stock of drinks like beers, sodas and wines plus more produce for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more beers, sodas and wines as well as more maize to sell

loans.name: Umsunai's Group

texts.en: Umsunai A. works as a director of the post office in her village. She also breeds cattle and cultivates fruits and vegetables. She has been doing this for 16 years (after the USSR collapsed, the collective farms broke up in 1994 and people were able to keep some parts of the land and continue to farm it). Umsunai is 51 and a widow. She has raised three sons and a daughter. Two sons and the daughter are married and live separately with their families. The youngest son lives with Umsunai and helps her with housework. Umsunai is the leader of this group. She wants to get a loan to purchase 150 liters of fuel, which is needed for farming. Dinar K. is 40 and married. She has three daughters and a son. The older daughter studies in college in Bishkek and the other children go to school. Dinar and her husband have been breeding cattle and cultivating fruits and vegetables since 1994. With money received from this loan, she will purchase 150 liters of fuel which is needed for sowing for the summer season. Mira S. is 32 and married. She has a daughter and a son. Both of them study at school. Mira and her husband have been breeding cattle and cultivating fruits and vegetables since 1994. In this way, they make money to improve their living conditions. Mira applied for a loan because she needs money to pay the tractor driver for his services and to purchase 200 liters of fuel for farming. Dinara Z. is the treasurer of the group. She is 41 and married. She has three daughters; all of them go to school. Dinara and her husband have been breeding cattle and cultivating fruits and vegetables for 16 years. In this way, they made some money to repair their house. Now Dinara needs a loan to purchase 150 liters of fuel which is needed for the sowing process. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3 P's concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase 150 liters of fuel which is needed for sowing

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is a 42-year-old widow with five children, ages 25, 21, 15, 13 and 5 years. She sells groceries, such as bananas, sweet potatoes and pumpkins, in the Gikomba open-air market. She started this business in 1997. She works hard to support her family and to educate her three youngest children. She also runs a salon to boost her income. She joined a group in Faulu Kenya and has learned how to save her money. 

She wants to take her first loan of Kes.20, 000 from Faulu Kenya. With this loan, she wants to buy bananas, sweet potatoes and pumpkins for her inventory. Mercy hopes to expand her business and to educate her children to university level.

loans.use: To buy bananas, sweet potatoes and pumpkins

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Tukwatilewamu Group, Jinja

texts.en:
To get into her customers good graces, 45 year old N. Zaituni had to improve her customer relationship skills. It was thirteen years ago when she came to terms with this fact. Since then her hotel (restaurant) business has obtained a firm footing in the heart of Jinja.

Before enforcing these measures to give her business a new lease of life, Zaituni’s business was fraught with all sorts of image problems. This was mostly due to the fact that most of the workers she hired had minimal training in good customer care. At length, this married mother of five buoyant children has never lived to regret her decision to train all her workers. Her business has been strengthened as a result.

Zaituni’s journey into business began with a small farming venture that she later dispensed with. Honesty and determination have gotten her far in this business, as she currently makes 100,000 shillings, a week. With this loan, she wants to purchase more foods for her hotel.

loans.use: To purchase more food items for her restaurant

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en: Zainab is married with two children. She has been in business trading in slippers for over eleven years now. She owns a stall along one of the busy streets in Makeni. She is very hard working and determined to succeed in business. For this reason, Zainab is seeking a loan to be able to buy goods that will increase her capital and then her profit. She intends to use the proceeds from the loan to educate her children up to university level and to build a house in the future.

loans.use: To buy shoes for her stall

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz J. is from the village of Magting in Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 42 years old. Luz is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Luz sells a variety of fruits in the local community. Luz has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Luz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luz has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000  PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Luz is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which to purchase more fruit to sell. This loan will be Luz's 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to educate her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy plastic products and enamel dishes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy new carpentry tools

loans.name: Jeralyn

texts.en:
Jeralyn M. is from the village of Magting in Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 26 years old. Jeralyn is married and has 2 young children. To make a living, Jeralyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Jeralyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Jeralyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jeralyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. Jeralyn is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Jeralyn's 4th loan HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Mamie United Business Group

texts.en:
Mamie W., who is holding the sign in the photograph, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Mamie United Business. She is 33 years old, single, and has two children. She was only able to attend school through 7th grade due to financial difficulties. 

For 3 years, she has been selling lappas (a traditional women's dress) and drinks at the Nezon Market in Harbel, Margibi County, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. 

She plans to use her 4,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 20,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more lappas and drinks. 

Her hope is to expand her business, be financially independent, and to continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more lappas and drinks.

loans.name: Charlene

texts.en:
Charlene L. is from the village of Balbagon in Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 31 years old. Charlene is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Charlene owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Charlene has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Charlene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Charlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used expand her business. Charlene is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Charlene's 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy products to sell

loans.name: Gilvenia

texts.en:
Gilvenia B. is a 33-year old married woman who lives in So. Dag-it, Brgy Okiot, Bais City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by engaging in a general store and fish vending businesses.

Gilvenia’s 40-year-old husband, Alexander, is a fisherman.  They have 2 children who are 10 and 13 years old. The children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Gilvenia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in her general store and fish-vending businesses. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 19,500 from her business activities.

Gilvenia is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 15,000 was used to fund the operations of her general store and fish vending business, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 10th cycle loan in the amount of Php 15,000, which she intends to use on her general store and her fish vending business. Gilvenia is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family: to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon--a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy clothes for the clothing shop

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic S. is a 38-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy. Mabuhay Sta Catalina Negros Oriental. She earns her living by buying and selling coconuts and by fishing.

Marivic’s husband Lowim is a fisherman, and they have 2 children who are currently going to school and who also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Marivic joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in buying and selling of coconut and fishing. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 6,000 from her business activities.

Marivic is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 19,000 was used to fund the operations of her fishing and buying and selling of coconut, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing, for her 7th cycle loan, the amount of Php 15,000, which she intends to use to add to her working capital. Marivic is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon--a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: additional working capital

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en: Emilia R. is from the village of Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 61 years old. Emilia is married and has nine adult children. To make a living, Emilia raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from selling copra (the dried meat of a coconut) to local community members. Emilia has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Emilia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to pay for the services extended by farm helpers to increase her crop yield. Emilia is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Emilia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mame Saye

texts.fr:
Madame Mame Saye Dramé s'active dans le commerce depuis 20 ans. Elle vend du poisson fumé, s'ché, des pâtes d'arachide et du Bissap au marché Grand Thiès.
Veuve à son état, cette dame souhaitait accroitre son activité. Ainsi, elle sollicite un prêt de 200 000  FCFA pour s'approvisionner en marchandises et diversifier également ses produits de vente. En plus de ce qu'elle vend, elle se lancer dans la vente du mil et du niébé ou haricot local.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mame Saye Dramé has been carrying out commercial activities for the past 20 years. She sells smoked and dried fish, groundnut paste (unsweetened peanut butter) and bissap (dried hibiscus flowers) at the Grand Thiès market. She is a widow and would like to expand her business. She is requesting a loan for 200,000 FCFA to acquire merchandise and also to diversify the products she sells. In addition to her current business, she wants to start selling millet and niébé (a local bean).

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: resupply merchandise

loans.name: Mamyaneboe Group

texts.en:
Peter C., who is holding the sign in the photo, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Mamyaneboe. He is 40 years old and married. He has two children and they are 3 and 7 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial difficulties. 

For 15 years, he has been selling used clothes at the Harbel Market in Harbel, Margibi County, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. 

He plans to use his 4,000-Liberian-Dollars portion of this 20,000-Liberian-Dollars group loan to buy more used clothes.

His dream is to grow his business, be financially independent and to continue to support his children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes.

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard K. W. is 27 years old, single, and has no children yet. He runs a motorcycle business in a residential area in Thika. He has been in this business for two and a half years now. He says the business is very good and the only major challenge comes during the rainy seasons due to bad roads. 

He is using his loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy another motorcycle to grow his business. In the future, he hopes to start a different type of business to add to his income. He also hopes to acquire a piece of land to develop for a family he hopes for. He is hardworking and polite.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Mouhamed El Moustapha

texts.fr:
Monsieur Mouhamed El Moustapha S. sollicitait un crédit de 200 000 FCFA pour continuer les travaux de construction de la maison de sa maman. Il est cependant un jeune commerçant et travaille avec son père  dans leur magasin  à Dakar. il vend des pièces détachées depuis 2 ans compte remboursé ce prêt avec sa maman qui travaille à l'hôpital.
de ce fait ce jeune célibataire compte sur ce crédit pour finir des travaux et secourir également sa maman
texts.en:
Mr. Mouhamed El Moustapha S. is requesting a loan for 200,000 FCFA to continue building his mother’s house. He is a young merchant working with his father in Dakar. His mother works at the hospital. He has been selling spare parts for the past two years. This will enable him to reimburse the loan he is counting on to finish the construction work and help his mother.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: continue construction work for his mother's house

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane A. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 32 years old. Mary Jane is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Jane owns & operates a business venture buying and selling coconut fruits and copra in the local community. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mary Jane joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000  PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more copra products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Mary Jane from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Nurzhamal's Group

texts.en:
Nurzhamal Z. is the leader of the group, she is 28 years old. Her husband works as a bus driver. They have a two-year-old son. Nurzhamal stays at home and takes care of her son. Nurzhamal owns a piece of land. In order to make some money she cultivates fruits and vegetables. She has been doing this work for a long time. When her husband is free, he helps her with the farming activities. The initial investment in this business was 3000 soms (65.28$) and now she makes 5000 soms (108.8$) per month. With money received from the loan Nurzhamal wants to purchase another piece of land for 6000 soms (130.57$). In the future she plans to repair the house.

Gulmerahon S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 43 and married. She has two sons and a daughter. In order to earn some money the older son went to work in Russia and the daughter studies at school. Gulmerahon sells convenience and stationery goods near the school. She also helps her husband in breeding cattle. They started breeding cattle 19 years ago, with the initial investment of 8000 soms (174$). Now they make 4000 soms (87$) per month. With money received from the loan, Gulmerahon wants to purchase a calf for breeding. In future she plans to buy a piece of land, to save some money to contribute to her son's wedding, and build a new house for him.

Munirahon R. is 28 years old. Her husband provides tractor and combine services. In order to make money Mubirahon and her husband breed cattle. They also sow wheat and potatoes. They have been doing this work for 10 years. The initial investment in that business activity was 3000 soms (65.28$) and now Mubirahon makes 5000 soms (108.8$) per month. She wants to get a loan to purchase a bull for breeding and fattening. In the future she plans to build a new house and to increase the number of cattle.

Ilham K. is 25 years old. He breeds poultry and cattle. His mom sells milk to make some money. Ten years ago, having sold some cattle, they started their business activity. The initial investment was 10000 soms (216.6$) and now Ilham makes 8000 soms (174$) per month. With money received from the loan, he will purchase a cow for breeding and fertilizers for farming. In the future, Ilham plans to purchase a piece of land, build a new house and to repair the parents' house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a piece of land for farming.

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth G. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 36 years old. Lilibeth is widowed and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Lilibeth owns & operates a business venture selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Lilibeth has been engaged in her business for less than a year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lilibeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lilibeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more fish to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Lilibeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Good Sisters Group

texts.en:
Oneikeh F., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Good Sisters. She is 40 years old, married, and has four children who range from 9 to 20 years old. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial difficulties. All of her children are attending school.

For 5 years, she has been selling cooking oil on a table in the Congo Town Community, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 10,000 Liberian dollars portion of this 38,000 Liberian dollars group loan to buy more cooking oil.

Her dream is to grow her business, make more profit, move from selling on a table to a shop, and continue to support her family.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Rouguietou

texts.fr: Mademoiselle Rouguietou B. est une ancienne agent de la Loterie Nationale Sénégalaise(LONASE). Cependant depuis 3 ans elle s'est virée dans le commerce de tisuus, parfums et ...etc. Elle s'approvisionne de l'extérieur, très souvent en Gambie ou Mauritanie, où les marchandises sont à bon prix. Ainsi, pour préparer son prochain voyage, elle sollicitait un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour compléter son budget
texts.en:
Miss Rouguietou B. is a former agent of the Senegalese National Lottery (LONASE). Three years ago she went into retail commerce: clothing fabric, perfume, etc. She gets her supplies from abroad, quite often in Gambia or Mauritania, where the merchandise is low-priced. Thus to prepare for her next trip, she is requesting a 100,000 FCFA loan to complete her budget.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: complete her budget to resupply products

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is a 61 year old married lady with six children. In the past ten years, she has been selling hair products. Besides the hair products, she does dairy farming and sells eggs to earn a living. She works hard to educate her children, who are still in school. She hopes to see her children through university levels in their studies. She joined Faulu Kenya in a group called Thuina Victory with the aim of saving money and accessing financial resources (loans). The group members guarantee each other's loans. She has requested for a loan of KES30, 000 to buy a dairy cow. She hopes to add more than five cows to her farm and to build a permanent shop for selling milk and eggs in the future.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Progressive Women Group

texts.en:
John Z., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Progressive Women. He is 37 years old, married and has two children who range from 18 to 22 years old. He was only able to attend school through eighth grade due to financial difficulties. 

For 17 years, he has been selling T-shirts and trousers on Carey Street in downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more T-shirts and trousers.

His dream is to grow his business, make more profit, venture into international business and continue to support his children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more T-shirts and trousers.

loans.name: Seynabou

texts.fr: Madame Seynabou S. est est une femme mariée âgée de 40 ans.  Elle tient un restaurant chez elle au quartier Grand Thiès et elle est très sollicitée dans ce business. Cette activité qu'elle adore très bien lui permet dit-elle de régler ses besoins et d'aider son mari à la charge de la maison depuis les 2 ans qu'elle s'y'est. Cependant, elle demande un prêt de 200 000 FCFA pour achever les travaux de construction d'un bâtiment chez elle
texts.en:
Mrs. Seynabou S. is a forty year old married woman. She runs a restaurant at her home in the neighborhood of Grand Thie. Her business is quite popular. She enjoys this business and over the past two years, it has allowed her to meet her personal needs and help her husband with the family expenses. At this time, she is requesting a 200,000 FCFA loan to pay for construction work to her house.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to pay for construction work to her house

loans.name: Togetherness Group

texts.en:
Annie V., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Togetherness. She is 44 years old, widowed and has 10 children who range from four to 28 years old. She currently attends the University of Liberia. 

For 10 years, she has been selling soap, sugar, tea, milk, eggs, toothpaste, toothbrushes and other provisions in the Congo Town Community, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 10,500 Liberian Dollars portion of this 45,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more soap, sugar, tea, milk, eggs, toothpaste, toothbrushes and other provisions.

Her dream is to grow her business, make more profit and continue to support her family.

loans.use: To buy more soap, sugar, tea, milk eggs, toothpaste, toothbrushes and other provisions.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en: Simon G. W. is forty nine years old. He is married. He and his wife have six children, to whom they hope to give a good education. He does his business of providing transport services to the people of Thika. He has been in this business for the last two years and he says the business is good. Although, at times,he is detracted by rains. He is using his loan of KES20,000 to buy another motorcycle to expand his business. He hopes to buy a farm with his profits. He is hardworking and cheerful.

loans.use: To purchase a motor cycle.

loans.name: Khardiata

texts.fr:
Madame Khardiata T. est une femme mariée âgée de 35 ans. Elle est mère de deux enfants âgés respectivement de 11 ans et 2 ans. Cette dame est une handicapée et se déplace sur une chaise roulante.  C'est en 2003 qu'elle s'est investie dans le commerce car d'après elle, la mendicité ne suffit pas pour subvenir à ses besoins. Elle vend cependant des tissus, encens et tous autres types de produits qui sont à bon marché et aimés par les clients. Elle est à sa première demande de crédit et compte s'approvisionner en produits.
Ainsi elle pourra avec ce business augmenter et diversifier leur revenu car son mari hancicapé aussi compte sur la mendicité pour nourir sa famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Khardiata T. is a married woman who is 35 years old. She is mother to two children, aged 11 and two years old respectively. This lady is disabled and moves around in a wheelchair. In 2003 she set herself up in business, since she considers that begging is not sufficient to provide for her needs. She thus sells fabrics, incense and all other types of products that are cheap and appreciated by her customers. This is the first time she has asked for a loan and she plans to stock up on products. As such, she will be able to increase and diversify her business with this income; her disabled husband also counts on begging to feed his family.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock up on fabrics and other diverse products

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel is 41 years old and a father of two. He has been in the bodaboda (motorbike) transport business for two years. Besides this business, he also rears and sells heifers and distributes water using his donkey cart. He belongs to Perfect group in Faulu Kenya. Since he joined the group, he has been able to invest in his business using his weekly savings with the group. He has requested for a loan of KES20,000 to buy a heifer. Samuel hopes to own a piece of land in the future. He dreams of buying a pick-up, in ten years, for transporting animal feed. He describes himself as ambitious and hardworking.

loans.use: To buy a heifer.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jivan

texts.en:
Upon serving two years in the army, Jivan B., a 29-year-old father, returned home and started a job search.  He found a job at a small hair salon and eventually picked up the skills needed to become a hair dresser.  Due to his sought-after skills and optimistic outlook on life, he established a small client base that enabled him to purchase a small salon. 

He lives with his wife, their four-year-old child, his mother and sister.  He is the main breadwinner of the family; however, his mom and sister help out with business.

Jivan’s salon currently serves only male customers, but he is looking forward to expanding his business to serve a female clientele, which has traditionally been a more lucrative endeavor.  Jivan is looking forward to expanding his business to secure the future of his child and family as they continue their lives on the outskirts of Yerevan.

loans.use: Opening of a women's section in a hair dressing salon

loans.name: Rael

texts.en: Rael is a 60 year old farmer. She is married to an accountant and she is blessed with three children. She has been farming for ten years and has one employee. She uses her income to provide for the family, including educating her two children who are in school. She is in Kyeni Ngeleni group, in Faulu Kenya, where she saves part of her income on a weekly basis. She has requested for a loan of KES15,000 to buy animal feeds. She hopes to improve her living standards in the future.

loans.use: To buy animal feed.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Malaika Group

texts.fr:
Yalala C. N. est entrepreneur,productrice de boisson locale communément appelé«Rutuku»,elle s’habille en blouse multicolore rouge noire,elle lève sa main sur la photo,excellente cliente de groupe de crédit Malaika,âgée de 57 ans,veuve,mère de 4 enfants dont 2 filles et 2 garçons respectivement mariés et ont tous leurs propres foyers.Yalala C. N. réside dans le quartier populaire Nyabushongo,bidon ville de la ville de Goma,commune de Karisimbi. 
Son mari est décèdé dans les années 2008 suite à une courte maladie.De façon sommaire,Rutuku est une boisson  alcoolisée d’environ 47% produite en base de solution ou mélange des moisissures des Farine de manioc, maïs, sorgho, etc. chauffée au feu à plus de 180o C,à travers une vase connectée à un cheminé d’évacuation de technologie locale. Les goutes raffinées d’évaporation issues de ce cheminé sont accueillies dans une cuvette et refroidies pour donner un gout d’une liqueur fort de Whisky. 
La veuve Yalala C. N. a commencé son business avec son fonds propre depuis 1984. Elle s’empruntait  les intrants de production de boisson locale Rutuku (maïs,farine,bois de chauffage,etc.)auprès de ses amis et connaissances, qu’elle payait après l’opération  sans aucun capital.C’était une façon de lui initier à l’auto prise en charge. Vue la charge de familiale et la vie seule,elle a évolué difficilement.Cependant avec le crédit de l’IMF Hekima, elle a retrouvé un equilibre social et économique.Dit-elle,Yalala C. N. a déjà réalisé plusieurs projets familiaux (achat de 2 parcelle,2 maisons construites,et elle accompagne ses enfants dans leurs foyers en toute responsabilité d’un  parent, et beaucoup d’autres projets.Yalala C. N. reste ambitieuse, malgré son statut de veuve,elle compte acheter une grande parcelle dans le quartier de V.I.P, comme himbi, Keshero, les volcans, etc.Avec  le crédit  de  l’IMF Hekima, la veuve Yalala C. N. souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant 2 sacs des Maïs, 4 sacs de farines maniocs, 2 tas de bois de chauffages, etc. 
Yalala C. N., explique le défi majeur de son activité de production de boissons locales Rutuku est lié aux ventes en  crédit, le manque ou rareté des bois de chauffage surtout comme l’Etat a déjà pris de mesures pénales aux destructeurs de l’environnement (vendeurs de bois de parc national). En plus parfois lorsque le mélange des intrants n’a pas bien être solutionné, on produit une boisson (liqueur whisky) non appréciée par les consommateurs, ils se réservent de l’acheter.
Vue l’avancement de son âge et les dures conditions de production de cette boisson, la veuve Yalala C. N.  souhaite changer  son activité  en vendant aussi les produits divers de commerce général a son domicile.  
La veuve Yalala C. N. remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants et petits fils.Elle reconnait de l’IMF Hekima sa banque de proximité pour le soulager comme elle n’a plus père, mère ni mari. Elle préservera a toute énergie, cette bonne relation de confiance et d’affaire en respectant leur contrat et politique de crédit de Hekima.
Le groupe Malaika est composé de 11 membres majoritairement femmes. Les membres  portent une tenue uniforme d’union et d’unité dans les affaires en  mémoire de la journée internationale de la femme du 8 mars 2010. Il sied de signaler sur la photo, il ya un coéquipier (une personne) qui se mit sur la photo sans faire parti du groupe de crédit. D’où visiblement, vous trouverez 12 personnes.
texts.en:
Yalala C. N. is an entrepreneur, producing a local drink known as 'Rutuku'. She is wearing a multicoloured jacket and waving her hand in the photograph. She is a reliable customer of the Malaika credit association, and is a 57 year-old widowed mother of four. Her two daughters and two sons are all married and have their own homes. Yalala lives in the popular Nyabushongo quarter, a shanty town in Goma, in the Karisimbi region. Her husband passed away in 2008, following a short illness. Rutuku is a 47% strength alcoholic beverage, made up of a solution of manioc flour fungus, corn, sorghum etc, heated to over 180 degrees centigrade through a vase that is joined to a locally-designed chimney pipe. The refined condensed droplets are collected in a bowl and cooled to give the taste of strong whisky. Yalala began this business with her own money in 1984. She borrowed all the ingredients for Rutuku (corn, flour, firewood etc) from friends and acquaintances that she paid back after completion - this was a way of kick-starting and taking charge of her work. Given the costs of family demands and single life, it has been difficult for her to grow her business. However, with a loan from the Hekima microfinance association, she has discovered a social and financial equilibrium. Yalala says that she has already completed several family projects (the purchase of 2 plots of land, the construction of two houses, and supporting her children in their homes, as a supportive parent should do, amongst other projects). Yalala remains ambitious, despite being widowed, and aims to buy a large plot of land in a VIP quarter, like Himbi, Keshero, the Volcanoes etc. With a Hekima loan, Yalala wishes to increase her business revenue and buying two bags of corn, four bags of manioc flour and two heaps of firewood. She explains that the main difficulty of producing this drink is down to credit sales and the scarcity of firewood (since the State has begun to clamp down on those who destroy the environment, such as sellers of wood from national parks). Furthermore, sometimes when the ingredients do not mix properly, a different liquor forms, and regular customers refrain from buying it. Given her advanced age and the difficult production process of this drink, Yalala wishes to modify her business activity, by also selling general products from her home. Yalala wishes to thank Hekima for the loans that she receives without any material guarantee, as thanks to these loans she can see to the needs of her children and grandchild. She recognises Hekima as the local bank that will support her, as she no longer has a mother, father, nor husband. She will do her best to maintain this good trusting business relationship, respecting Hekima's loan contract and policy. The Malaika group is made up of 11 members, mostly women. They are wearing a uniform in recognition of the international day of the woman on the 8th of March 2019. (There is also another individual in the photograph who does not belong to the microfinance group, hence 12 people in total in the photo).

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing 2 bags of corn, 4 bags of manioc flour, two heaps of firewood

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Stanley

texts.en: Stanley M. N. is twenty two years old, single and has no children yet. He does a transport business and provides the services to the people of Thika. He has been in this business for the last two years and he says the business is good. The only major challenge is the rains, which make it difficult to run the business. He is using his loan of KES20,000 to buy another motor cycle to expand his business. He hopes to buy a vehicle for taxi business. He describes himself as cheerful and social.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a 48 year old married lady with four children. She has been practicing dairy farming for the past twenty years. Since she joined a group in Faulu Kenya, she has been able to buy a dairy cow through her savings. She has requested for a loan of KES35,000 to repair the cow shed for her cows. She hopes to become financially stable in the future. She dreams of being the main supplier of milk and heifer breeds in the future.

loans.use: To repair the cow shed for her cows.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is 53 years old and married with four children. He has been earning a living through dairy farming for 25 years. He sells his milk to Githunguri Dairy Sacco, who later distributes the milk. For his business to stabilize, he joined a group called Perfect in Faulu Kenya. In this group, he saves his money weekly and uses his savings to boost his business. He has requested for a loan of KES10,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy a dairy cow. He hopes to become financially stable in the future.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Titus

texts.en: Titus is 54 years old, married and has two children. He sells coffins to earn a living. He started this business five years ago and has employed one person. He also does farming for more income. He joined Masaku Ushindi group so as to access a loan from Faulu Kenya. This is because the group members guarantee each other's loans. He has requested for a loan of KES25,000 to buy timber for making coffins. He hopes to build a house for his family, in the future.(The photo shows his wood vanishes in the background).

loans.use: To buy timber for making coffins.

loans.name: Kimanga Group

texts.en:
Meet Dr. Marysia K. and the Kimanga Group.  Marysia is 37 years old, married, and has a three-year-old daughter. Marysia studied to be a doctor, but before she started practicing medicine, she gave birth to her daughter who was premature.  She decided to stay home and care for her baby.  While at home, she decided to start her own catering business, which she did shortly after her daughter's birth.  

With a small amount of money from her husband, Marysia began buying some catering supplies and offering her services for events such as weddings and kitchen parties.  In 2009, her friend introduced her to Tujijenge Tanzania, and Marysia has now had three loans.  With the previous loans, Marysia bought tablecloths and fabric for decorations, serving dishes, buffet tables, plates, a charcoal cooker, and a gas cooker.  This has allowed her to grow her business, which now employs 8-10 staff.  Profits vary depending on the number of events Marysia caters, but can be up to 3,000,000 Tsh per month (about $2100).  

This is Marysia's first Motisha loan. A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended.  Marysia has some big events coming up, and she will use this loan to buy extra drinking glasses and fabric for decorations.  Marysia dreams of growing her business and if she makes a profit from this loan, she will save to buy a music system, and someday to make a trip to China to buy more catering and decoration supplies. Marysia also recently started working as a medical doctor during the week, and greatly enjoys her two different types of work. 

Marysia is the President of the Kimanga Group.  The 10 group members will hold each other accountable for repaying the loan. In the photo, Marysia is the middle of the back row, wearing a striped polo shirt.

loans.use: To buy glasses and decorations

loans.name: George

texts.en: George is a married man with three school-aged children.  He started a business for painting and repairing jacks four months ago.  He is a member of Mijingo group in Faulu Kenya.  Through the group, he can get a loan from Faulu Kenya.  Therefore, he has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to buy spray pumps and paints. He hopes to stabilize his business in ten years.

loans.use: To buy spray pumps and paints

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Yoma

texts.en: Yoma R. is currently in the business of selling cocks and hens and is requesting a loan to purchase turkeys to sell. Yoma is 39 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend her business by constructing enough room for keeping domestic birds to sell. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase turkeys to sell

loans.name: Singida Group

texts.en:
Meet Rukia J. and the Singida Group.  Rukia is 44 years old, married and has three children ages 10, 15 and 22 years old.  All of her children go to school.

For 16 years, Rukia has been running a clothing business.  She started out selling used clothes, but has grown her business and now she sells madila, which are long embroidered robes often worn by Muslim women in Tanzania.  Rukia works from 9 am until 6 pm each day and earns a profit of about 400,000 Tanzanian shillings ($270) per month.

She used her first loan from Tujijenge to increase her stock of madila and will use this loan to buy garments from Mombassa (Kenya) and India.  If she earns a profit from this loan, Rukia will continue to increase her business inventory and will pay for her children's school fees.  EventuA. she hopes to build a larger home for her family.

Rukia is a member of the Singida Group.  The group members will hold each other accountable for paying back this Motisha loan.  A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended. 

In the photo, Rukia is in the front row wearing an orange madila and a red headscarf.

loans.use: To increase clothing stock

loans.name: Cicila

texts.en: Cicila A. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, onions and cooking oil and is requesting a loan to stock fresh and dried fish to sell. Cicila is 45 years old and is widowed. She has six children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock fresh and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Lukondo Group

texts.en:
Meet Ismail Y. and the Lukondo Group. Ismail is 30 years old and has two small boys. They go to school and so does Ismail's 16-year-old younger brother who he supports.  For the past 9 years, Ismail has run a small business selling cakes and renting decorations for weddings and other events.  He starts work around 8am and can work as late as midnight if he needs to collect his decorations from a party.  Ismail's profit varies depending on the number of events he services, but it can be as much as 400,000 TSH a month (about $270). He will use this loan to purchase decorative light bulbs and cloth to improve the selection of products that he can rent.  Ismail will save any profit from this loan so that he can buy more decorative equipment and a car, which will help him transport the rental equipment more easily.  Eventually Ismail would like to build his own house.

Ismail is the President of the Lukundo Group, which means love in Kipale, one of the many indigenous languages spoken in Tanzania.  The group's members run a variety of businesses such as a saloon, a café, and sales of food, charcoal, clothes and hardware.  They will hold each other accountable for paying back this loan.  

In the photo, Ismail is standing in the back row wearing an orange shirt.

loans.use: To buy decorative bulbs and cloth

loans.name: Lily

texts.en: Lily Y. is currently in the business of selling dresses and bedsheets at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bedsheets and dresses to sell. Lily is 24 years old and is married to a businessman. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy two sewing machines. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bedsheets and dresses to sell

loans.name: Joice

texts.en: Joice D. is currently in the business of selling beans and maize flour at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of pulses (groundnuts, peas, cowpeas) and soya beans to sell. Joice is 38 years old and is married to a watchman. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store for her goods. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of pulses and soya beans to sell

loans.name: Kihumulo Twimukye Women's Group, Mubende

texts.en:
B. Lauben is a 32-year-old happily-married father of four children who has run a salon business for five years in Ikula, Mubende. With all his efforts, he has been able to maintain it earning him 100,000 Ugandan shillings a week. This income has always been significant in contributing towards his family’s welfare.

Lauben’s current setback is lacking additional capital for purchasing salon materials like shampoo, hair oils and a drier, basically demanded lady customers. He works on both ladies' and men's hairstyles and he is grateful that he learnt the trade first and now he is a pro and customers like it.

This loan will help Lauben in buying a new drier for his salon. Lauben appears at the top left corner  in the small photo just like in the big group photo.

loans.use: To purchase a new drier for his salon

loans.name: Miramar Feminina 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Nery is the coordinator of her group Miramar Feminina, and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the lush, rugged Samana peninsula, an area with a nascent tourism industry where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and three children.

Nery is excited to be taK. her 10th loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running an ambulatory food stand in which she sells basic staples of the Dominican diet such as chicken, yuca, lentils, fish, and salad. Additionally, she will invest in a freezer to store her goods in her home.  She will use the profits to purchase clothing and medicine for her children, investing in her education as well as the education of her children and saving towards finishing construction on her home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy chicken, yuca, lentils, fish, salad and a freezer

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is the mother of five – her youngest is a boy of seven months. Her husband is employed by the Kenyan Navy and her four older girls are all in school.

Amina runs a small restaurant and has been in business for just a year. Before she started the restaurant, she was unemployed. She sells her food to those in her neighborhood and to passersby. She says some of the largest business challenges she faces are competition, and collecting money from debtors.

Amina’s aspirations for the future of her business are to be able to own her own plot of land in nearby Kilifi.

Amina’s largest personal expenses are school fees, food for her family, and medication. She currently rents her house, but does not have electricity or piped water.

loans.use: To buy a stock of beans, rice, Irish potatoes, sugar, baking flour and cooking oil
